instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that keeps rebooting when loading OSX. The client told me that first, the cam stopped working, and them it just starts to rebooting.
Already replace the disk, but with the same results. I've notice a bit of corrosion on the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and I've lift it up and soldered back again , but with the same result.

Booting without the cam doesn't solved the problem.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
threads.message:
Did you try USB macOS?
Also try in safe mode and SMC bypass.
Worth to try known good BIOS too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
threads.message:
Removing <RESISTOR>R2030</RESISTOR> seams to have worked. 
It boots again! Thanks!
Do I need to leave it without the resistor, or can I check some components to make sure if the cam can be saved?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
threads.message:
Did you check <RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR> first? You can also try to replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.
If there are some instabilities on the clock it can cause the camera IC to crash, and in turn crash the camera driver and cause macOS to reboot when it tries to load it.
By removing <RESISTOR>R2030</RESISTOR>, the camera IC is turned off so camera won't work but at least it doesn't crash.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A rebooting
threads.message:
Yes, I checked <RESISTOR>R2042</RESISTOR> and it was OK. 3.3v goes through  it to the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. 
I'll replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and see what happens.

Thanks!
